Composed by 500 great arhats and othersğŸ”½Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Xuanzang on imperial command

Tripiá¹­aka master Xuanzang respectfully translated by imperial decreeğŸ”½20. The second part of the aggregate of matter, the fourth section of the ten-chapter treatise, the twentieth. The latent tendencies of the eye faculty up to the latent tendencies of ignorance to be eliminated by cultivation in the formless realm.ğŸ”½ğŸ”½

For each additional latent tendency, should it be said to have initial thought and sustained thought, or to have only sustained thought without initial thought, or to have neither initial thought nor sustained thought?
Why is this treatise composed?
The answer is: in order to stop other schools and reveal the correct principle.
That is to say, some say:
Because initial thought and sustained thought are the coarse and fine aspects of the mind, they exist up to the peak of existence.
All defiled minds have initial thought and sustained thought.
Therefore, initial thought and sustained thought exist in the three realms.
Like the UpÄyikÄ school.
In order to refute that view, it is shown that only in the desire realm and the first meditative absorption,
in the preliminary concentration, there is initial thought and sustained thought.
In the intermediate concentration, there is only sustained thought without initial thought.
In the second meditative absorption up to the peak of existence, there is neither initial thought nor sustained thought.
For this reason, this treatise is composed.
The latent tendencies that increase with the eye faculty are of three kinds.
The latent afflictions that increase in dependence on the eye faculty.
Pervade the five stages of the desire realm and the four meditations, and are eliminated by cultivation.
In this way, the latent afflictions, if in the desire realm or the first meditation, have investigation and analysis.
If in the intermediate meditation, they have no investigation but only analysis.
If in the second, third, or fourth meditations, they have neither investigation nor analysis. Therefore it is said they have all three.
The latter statement that they have all three should be understood in the same way.
However, the stage without investigation and analysis
is either many or few.
The latent afflictions that increase in dependence on the female faculty
have investigation and analysis.
The latent afflictions that increase in dependence on it are only in the desire realm.
The latent afflictions that increase in dependence on the eye, ear, and body consciousness realms
may have investigation and analysis or may have no investigation but only analysis.
Although the five consciousnesses such as the eye consciousness have investigation and analysis,
in the first meditation,ğŸ”½they are also the objects of grasping of the latent afflictions of the intermediate meditation.
Therefore, the latent afflictions that increase in dependence on them also have no investigation but only analysis.
The latent afflictions that increase in the first dhyÄna,
may be with initial and sustained thought, or without initial thought but only sustained thought.

The phrase first dhyÄna generally refers to the three stages of the preliminary concentration, the fundamental dhyÄna, and the intermediate dhyÄna of the first dhyÄna. The dharmas of these three stages are referred to as having two types.
Even if it only refers to the fundamental dhyÄna, it must also have two types.
This is because the latent afflictions of the intermediate dhyÄna of the first dhyÄna and so forth take the three stages as their objects.
The remaining text is easy to understand, so it is not analyzed.
Each of the latent afflictions that increase in the eye faculty up to the latent afflictions abandoned by cultivation in the formless realm,

translated: should be said to be associated with the faculty of pleasure, the faculty of pain, the faculty of joy, the faculty of depression, or the faculty of equanimity?
Why does this treatise ask this question?
The answer is: in order to stop other schools and reveal the correct principle.
This refers to those who hold the view
that the two feelings of pleasure and pain, according to the body on which they depend,
exist from the desire realm up to the fourth dhyÄna.
The two feelings of joy and depression, according to the mind on which they depend,
exist from the desire realm up to the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
In order to refute this view, it is shown that the pleasant feeling exists only in the desire realm and the first and third meditative absorptions.
The two feelings of pain and sorrow exist only in the desire realm.
The feeling of joy exists only in the desire realm and the first two meditative absorptions.
Only the feeling of equanimity exists in all realms.
Or, there is another view that
the mind and mental factors arise in sequence and are not mutually associated.
Like the VÄtsÄ«putrÄ«yas.
In order to refute this view, it is shown that the mind and mental factors arise simultaneously and have the meaning of association.
For this reason, this treatise is composed.
The latent tendencies that increase with the eye faculty are associated with four faculties, excluding the faculty of pain.
The latent tendencies that increase with the eye faculty are common to the desire realm and form realm, in five stages, and are eliminated through cultivation.
If they are in the desire realm, they are associated with the faculties of joy, sorrow, and equanimity.
If they are in the first two meditative absorptions, they are associated with the faculties of joy and equanimity.
If they are in the third meditative absorption, they are associated with the faculties of pleasure and equanimity.
If they are in the fourth meditative absorption, they are only associated with the faculty of equanimity.
Therefore, it is said in general that they are associated with four faculties.
The faculty of suffering is only associated with the five consciousnesses.
Because in the five consciousnesses there are no dormant afflictions that take the eye faculty, etc., as their objects, they are definitely not associated with the faculty of suffering.
The dormant afflictions that increase the female faculty are associated with three faculties, excluding the faculties of pleasure and suffering.
The dormant afflictions that increase the female faculty exist only in the desire realm.
Because pleasure and suffering in the desire realm both exist in the five consciousnesses.
They are not associated with pleasure or suffering.
The dormant afflictions that increase the mental faculty are associated with five faculties.
Because the mental faculty is associated with the five feelings, the bonds of association are associated with five faculties.
If the bonds of objects are four, excluding suffering.
The dormant afflictions that increase the three samÄdhis.
Are associated with four faculties, excluding the faculty of suffering.
Because the faculty of suffering only takes the five objects such as form as its objects, not samÄdhi, etc.
Because the three samÄdhis are only pure.
The dormant afflictions that do not increase are not discussed here. The remaining text is easy to understand and does not need further explanation.
Fearing that the wise would become weary and discouraged.
From the eye faculty up to the ignorance to be eliminated by cultivation in the formless realm.
Who possesses which?
Who does not possess which?
Why does this treatise ask this question?
The answer is: in order to refute other schools and reveal the correct principle.
This refers to those who hold the view
that the real nature of possession and non-possession does not exist, and they are only provisionally established.
In order to show that the nature of possession and non-possession is a real entity.
If it were not so,
it would contradict the sutras.
As the sutras say,
One should know that such a person possesses good dharmas and bad dharmas.
The sutras also say,
I possess the ten powers, the four forms of fearlessness, and so forth.
If there were no such thing as possession and non-possession,

then the distinction between ordinary beings and sages, between those in training and those beyond training, between those who have severed wholesome roots and those who have not,ğŸ”½would all be impossible to establish.
Because the definitive causes and conditions cannot be found.
However, the one who possesses and the one who does not possess are conventionally existent.
If the nature of possession and the nature of non-possession are ultimately existent.
Like death and rebirth are conventionally existent.
The dharmas of death and rebirth are ultimately existent.ğŸ”½The one who enters and exits concentration is conventionally existent.
The concentration that is entered and exited is ultimately existent.
The agent and the experiencer are conventionally existent.
The karmic retribution of karma is ultimately existent.
In this way, the nature of possession and non-possession is ultimately existent.
The designation of the one who possesses and the one who does not possess is conventionally existent.
That is to say, if there is the nature of possession in the body, it is called the one who possesses.
If there is the nature of non-possession in the body, it is called the one who does not possess.
Like a tree, etc., is a false color, etc.
The four elements are real.
In this way, the pudgala is false.
The five skandhas such as form are real.
In the continuity of the body of this false person,
Based on acquisition and non-acquisition, there are dharmas that are possessed and not possessed.
For this reason, this treatise is composed.
The eye faculty, the form realm, and the desire realm are already acquired and not lost.
Possession.
Because the gods of the form realm all have faculties,
They definitely possess the five faculties such as the eye.
This statement about having faculties is based on the manifest.
The female and male faculties, even if unmanifest or non-existent, are also called having faculties.
Moreover, it is said that one has faculties because they may all possess them.
Not all exist. Do not worry that suffering, etc. also exist there.
And the desire realm is already acquired.
This refers to the stage of pÄriplava. Because they are not lost.
This refers to not rotting, not falling, not being eaten by worms, and not being harmed.
The formless realm and the desire realm are not acquired and are lost, and are not possessed.
Because the formless realm lacks form, it does not possess the faculties such as the eye.
And the desire realm is not acquired.
This refers to the stages of kalala, arbuda, peÅ›in, and ghana.
Those who have already lost it.
Those whose nose, tongue, and ears have rotted, fallen off, or been eaten by worms.
The body faculty is accomplished in the desire and form realms.
Because one who is born in the form realm must have the body faculty.
It is not accomplished in the formless realm because they have no form.
The female and male faculties are accomplished in the desire realm by those who have not lost them.
As explained for the eye faculty.
The form and formless realms, and those in the desire realm
who have not yet obtained them or have already lost them are not accomplished.
The form and formless realms have no female or male faculties because they have no sexual desire.
Because they are disgusted with and abandon these faculties when born in those realms.
Because the form and formless realms have no coarse food.
Because these faculties must be based on coarse food.
Because these faculties are based on shamelessness and lack of conscience.
Also, because the female and male faculties are useless to them.
Question: If that is so,
then the nose and tongue should also be absent.
Because there is no function of smelling scents and tasting flavors there.
Answer: The two faculties of nose and tongue are useful there.
That is, adorning the body and engaging in speech.
The two faculties of male and female make the body ugly.
Those with a sense of shame and dishonor must conceal them.
The Venerable Subhagupta says:
Because there is no karma that can attract those two realms.
Question: Since the form and formless realms are devoid of the male faculty, they should not be considered men.
Answer: Because the form and formless realms have the function of men, they are called men.
The function of men is:
That is, being able to detach from desire and accomplish good deeds is called being a man.
As a sutra says:
The four directions and four fruits are all called men.
It is not that all women are devoid of the directions and fruits.
As a sutra says:
This great mother
Although she is a woman, she enters the noble path.
Obtaining the fruit and exhausting the defilements is also called being a man.
Regarding this meaning, four sentences should be made.
There may be men who do not possess the male faculty.
That is, those born in the form and formless realms, etc.
There are those who possess the male faculty but are not called men.
Such as eunuchs and hermaphrodites.
There are those who are men and also possess the male faculty.
Such as those who possess the male faculty and are free from the passion of desire, etc.
There are those who are not men and also do not possess the male faculty.
Such as excluding the above characteristics.
For those born from wombs, eggs, or moisture who gradually die,
they gradually abandon the six material faculties such as the eyes.
Within the body faculty, there is also gradual abandonment.
Such as the hands, feet, etc.
If they abandon all the atoms of the body faculty, they will immediately die.
If in hell, the limbs and joints are unraveled,
and even when rotten, there is still the body faculty.
Some say:
At that time, there are also the eyes, etc.
If they were completely absent,
they should not be reborn later.
Because once the retribution is severed, it does not continue again.
Some say:
In the hells, the six faculties such as the eyes are severed and then continue again.
Because they are drawn by karma.
Because that is the nature of the destinies.
Just as when a humanâ€™s limbs and joints are severed, they cannot be reconnected.
In hell, when limbs and joints are severed, they are quickly regenerated.
The nature of the destinies is such that they cannot be compared to each other.
Therefore, the eyes and so on of hell beings are severed and then regenerated.
The body faculty is never completely severed.
If it were completely severed, there would be no possibility of regeneration.
Because it is the support of the other faculties.
There are some extremely subtle particles of the body faculty
that, based on these, later regenerate the limbs and joints.
The body faculty within the limbs and joints is severed and then regenerated, just like the eye faculty and so on.
Other masters say:
Even though the limbs of hell beings are severed into a hundred or a thousand pieces,
there is still a body faculty within each piece.
Because there is continuity among the pieces.ğŸ”½It is like the kapok tree and lotus root and stem,
or like a gourd that is broken into pieces but remains connected.
If they were not connected, the body faculty would be nonexistent.
Because no single sentient being has two bodies.
But in the world we see that when the bodies of worms are cut,
they still move because they are turned by the force of the wind. They do not have the body faculty.
The faculties of life, mind, and indifference are all possessed by all sentient beings.
Because they are all possessed in the three realms and the nine stages, and are always possessed.
The faculty of pleasure is possessed by those below the heaven of universal purity and by noble ones born above.
Those born above as ordinary beings do not possess it. The faculty of pleasure exists only in the desire realm, the first trance state, and the third trance state.
It is either contaminated or uncontaminated.
That of the desire realm and the first trance state is only contaminated.
That of the third trance state is of both kinds.ğŸ”½Those who are contaminated do not possess it when born above or when falling below.
Those who are uncontaminated do not abandon it when born in higher stages.
Uncontaminated faculties are only possessed by those who attain the fruits of the path or who retrogress from the path.
Question: If one is born in the second trance state but has not yet abandoned the defilements of the second trance state,
what stage of the faculty of pleasure does one possess?
Answer: They possess the defiled faculty of pleasure of the third meditation.
If they have already been freed from the defilements of the second meditation,
and have attained the undefiled faculty of pleasure of the third meditation,
therefore if born below the heaven of universal purity, they all possess the faculty of pleasure.
The phrase universal purity generally refers to one's own stage, and mentioning the latter indicates the former.
The rest are all like this.
Question: Can there be noble ones born in the fourth meditation and above who do not possess the faculty of pleasure?
Some say there can be.
Namely, those who have already been freed from the defilements of the third meditation,
relying on the second meditation and the three lower stages, enter the correct state of freedom from birth.
Having attained the fruit of non-returner, they do not subsequently give rise to the path to the destination.
At the end of life, they are reborn in the fourth meditation and above.
They do not possess the faculty of pleasure.
The judges say:
They should not say this.
If one who has already been freed from the defilements of the higher stages relies on the lower stages to enter the correct state of freedom from birth,
having attained the fruit, one will certainly give rise to the path to the superior fruit.
If one cultivates the pure [attainments] of the upper stages and obtains the cessation of the upper stages, then one's life ends.
It is like one who has already separated from the defilements of the first three or four stages of the desire realm.
Or the seventh or eighth stage of defilement.
Enters the correct stage of separation from birth.
Having attained that fruit, one necessarily gives rise to the path of the superior fruit.
Cultivating the superior pure [attainments] and obtaining the superior cessation, then one's life ends.
Question: If one has already separated from the defilements of the third meditation stage,
Relying on the second meditation stage and the three lower stages,
The faith-liberated one sharpens their faculties and becomes one who attains through views.
They do not give rise to the subsequent path and end their life, but are reborn in the fourth meditation stage and above.
What faculty of pleasure do they accomplish?
Answer: If they attain mastery over the upper stages, when they sharpen their faculties,
They are also able to cultivate the pure faculty of pleasure of the upper stages.
Even if they do not attain mastery over the upper stages,

Having attained that fruit, they necessarily also give rise to the path of the superior fruit and cultivate the pure [attainments] of the upper stages, then their life ends. Therefore, the noble ones who are reborn above the Pure Abodes,
Definitely accomplish the pure faculty of pleasure.
The attainment of the faculty of joy should be explained in the same way.
The faculty of suffering is attained in the desire realm.
It is not attained in the form and formless realms.
Sentient beings in the desire realm, even Buddhas, attain the faculty of suffering.
Because suffering arises when adverse conditions oppress, and this is not due to discrimination.
The faculty of suffering does not exist in the form and formless realms.
Because they are nourished by the power of superior samÄdhi.
Because there are no adverse conditions.
Because there is no unwholesome karma or afflictions.
Moreover, the form and formless realms are superior realms.
That is to say, even superior bodies in inferior realms have the suffering faculty.
Like the Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and great sages in the desire realm.
If inferior bodies in superior realms also have no suffering faculty.
Like ordinary beings in the form and formless realms.
It is like when there is a disaster in the autumn, even the fine crops are eaten by insects, etc.
When there is no disaster in the autumn, even the inferior weeds are not eaten by insects, etc.ğŸ”½The faculty of sorrow is attained by those not yet free from the defilements of desire.
It is not attained by those already free from the defilements of desire.
The faculty of sorrow definitely arises due to discrimination.
Those who have not yet separated from desire give rise to sorrow due to discrimination.
When those who have already separated from desire give rise to discrimination, they do not give rise to sorrow and dejection.
Therefore, if the faculty of sorrow is of a wholesome nature and one is also separated from desire-attachment, it is also not accomplished.
Because it is attracted and emitted by the afflictions of the desire realm.
The three pure faculties have already been attained and not lost.
One is accomplished in what has not yet been attained.
What has already been lost is not accomplished.
The faculty of being able to understand what has not yet been understood is called already attained upon entering the path of seeing.
The faculty of having understood is called not lost when the knowledge of the class of the path is not presently manifest.

The faculty of being able to understand what has not yet been understood is called not yet attained when the receptivity to the knowledge of the factors with regard to suffering is not presently manifest.
The faculty of having understood is called already lost after the knowledge of the class of the path is presently manifest.
The faculty of having understood is called already attained when the knowledge of the class of the path has already arisen or one has regressed from the fruit of arhatship.
The faculty of final knowledge is called not lost when the knowledge of extinction is not presently manifest.
The faculty of having understood is called not yet attained when the knowledge of the class of the path is not presently manifest or one has not yet regressed from the fruit of arhatship.
The faculty of final knowledge is called already lost after the knowledge of extinction is presently manifest.
If the faculty of perfect knowledge is present, it is called already attained.
If one is an arhat who has not regressed, it is called not lost.
If the knowledge of exhaustion is not present, it is called not yet attained.
If one has regressed from the fruit of arhatship, it is called already lost.
The elements of body, form, sound, and touch.
Attained in the desire and form realms.
Not attained in the formless realm.
The question is, the elements of body, form, and touch are possible,
but how is the element of sound always attained?
There is an explanation.
The element of sound must arise from the aggregation and separation of the primary elements.
If sentient beings are in the desire or form realms,
the primary elements are always present, so sound is always produced.
The evaluators say that this explanation should not be given.
If the four primary elements must always produce sound,
what primary elements produce this sound?
If it is produced by those [primary elements], it should be called resistant form produced by one set of four primary elements.
If it is said to be produced by other [primary elements], those other primary elements must also produce sound.
In this way, there would be an infinite regress.
It should be explained as follows.
In the bodies of sentient beings born in the desire and form realms.
Sentient beings born in the desire realm or form realm have many of the four great elements in their bodies.
When they strike each other, sound is produced.
When they do not strike each other, sound does not arise.
Although there is necessarily the sound element in one's body,
not all parts of the body emit sound everywhere.
The Venerable BodhyÄá¹£raya says:
Sound is not always accomplished in the desire realm or form realm.
This treatise text is based on the majority of cases.
The eye, ear, and body consciousness elements,
below the Brahma world and born in the upper three meditations,
are accomplished when present.
When not present,
and in the formless realm, they are not accomplished.
This means that if born in the desire realm or first meditation,
they are accomplished according to circumstances.
Among the three defiled or wholesome consciousnesses and the indeterminate ones,
those with habitual tendencies are also always accomplished.
Like the superior deportment, craftsmanship, and fruition of mastery.
If born in the second meditation or above,
Only neutral dharmas are accomplished when they are present.
If they are not present, they are not accomplished.
Because the five consciousnesses are weak by nature.
When they arise in other realms, their power is not strong.
If the mind of transformation, etc., in the mental consciousness
Even if born in other realms, its power is also strong, so it is accomplished even if not present.
The pure and unconditioned dharmas, such as the sphere of mental objects, are always accomplished.
This means that all sentient beings do not fail to accomplish cessation not due to deliberation.
The dharmas that are not to be eliminated should be understood in the same way.
The three concentrations are like the truth of the path, etc.
Those who have already attained are not yet accomplished.
Because once attained, one never regresses or abandons them.
Because one cultivates and attains them just before parinirvÄá¹‡a.
After parinirvÄá¹‡a, one is no longer counted among sentient beings.
Therefore one cannot say that one fails to accomplish them.
The remaining text is easy to understand, so it is not distinguished.
The eye faculty up to the formless realm.
When each of the latent afflictions to be eliminated by cultivation is completely known,
among the ninety-eight latent afflictions,
how many latent afflictions are completely known?
How many of the nine fetters are exhausted?
Question: Why is this treatise composed?
Answer: It is in order to refute other schools and reveal the correct principle.
That is to say, some hold the view that
form dharmas are also subject to elimination by insight.
In order to refute this idea and show that all form dharmas are not subject to elimination by insight,
some also hold the view that
ordinary beings are unable to eliminate the latent afflictions subject to elimination by insight.
Others hold the view that
ordinary beings are unable to eliminate any latent afflictions, only able to suppress them.
In order to refute these ideas and show that ordinary beings are able to eliminate the latent afflictions subject to elimination by insight in the desire realm up to the sphere of nothingness,
only excluding the peak of existence,
this treatise is composed.
However, there are broadly two kinds of complete knowledge:
first, complete knowledge as wisdom;
second, complete knowledge as elimination.
Here, the treatise is composed based only on complete knowledge as elimination.
Although cessation is analytical cessation, since it is the fruit of the knowledge of elimination, it is called knowledge of elimination.
It is like the six sense bases being called the fruit of action, for the name of the cause is applied to the fruit.ğŸ”½The same is true of knowledge of elimination.
Furthermore, in this context, it is said that one who obtains knowledge of elimination
is one who eliminates them completely.
When one finally eliminates them completely, it is called obtaining knowledge of elimination.
It is not necessary to speak only in terms of the nine kinds of knowledge of elimination.
When the eye faculty obtains knowledge of elimination, desire for form is exhausted.
The eye faculty is in five stages,
that is, the realm of desire and the four meditations. When desire for the realm of desire is exhausted,
the eye faculty of the realm of desire obtains knowledge of elimination.
Up to when desire for the fourth meditation is exhausted, the eye faculty of the fourth meditation obtains knowledge of elimination.
Now, in terms of finally obtaining knowledge of elimination,
it is said that when desire for form is exhausted, knowledge of elimination is obtained.
The rest are all like this.
When ordinary beings obtain knowledge of elimination of the thirty-one kinds of latent afflictions,
at that time ordinary beings eliminate completely the thirty-one kinds of latent afflictions eliminated by seeing and cultivation in the realm of form.
Therefore, there is no exhaustion of bonds.
It means that at that time, there is not a single bond that is completely exhausted.
Although the latent afflictions are also called bonds,
in this context, it refers to the teachings of the eighteen realms.
It means that the latent afflictions are based on the ninety-eight,
while the bonds are based on the nine.
The rest should be understood in the same way.
When the noble ones attain the complete knowledge of the three latent afflictions,
it means that at that time, the noble ones only attain the complete knowledge of the three latent afflictions that are to be eliminated through cultivation in the form realm.
There is no exhaustion of bonds.
It means that among the nine bonds, there is not a single bond that is exhausted.
When the complete knowledge of the male and female faculties is attained, it means the exhaustion of desire.
It means that the male and female faculties are only in the desire realm,
so the exhaustion of desire is called the attainment of complete knowledge.
When ordinary beings attain the complete knowledge of the thirty-six latent afflictions,
it means that at that time, ordinary beings eliminate the thirty-six latent afflictions that are to be eliminated through the path of seeing and cultivation in the desire realm.
The exhaustion of the three bonds,
it means that at that time, the bonds of anger, jealousy, and stinginess are completely exhausted among the nine bonds.
As for the noble ones who attain the complete knowledge of the four latent afflictions,
at that time, the noble ones only attain the complete knowledge of the four latent afflictions that are to be eliminated through cultivation in the desire realm.
As for the exhaustion of the three fetters, it is explained as it is for ordinary beings.
However, when the attainment of the complete knowledge of the life faculty in the fetter of anger, which is only to be eliminated through cultivation,
As for the exhaustion of desire for the formless realm,ğŸ”½it refers to the time when the desire for the nine stages is exhausted.
When the desire for the desire realm is exhausted,
the attainment of the complete knowledge of the life faculty of the desire realm occurs.
Up to the time when the desire for the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception is exhausted,
the attainment of the complete knowledge of the life faculty of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception occurs.
Now, based on the ultimate attainment of complete knowledge,
it is said that the exhaustion of desire for the formless realm is called the attainment of complete knowledge.
As for the attainment of the complete knowledge of the three latent afflictions,
at that time, the exhaustion of the three latent afflictions to be eliminated through cultivation in the formless realm is severed.
As for the exhaustion of the three fetters,
it is because the three fetters of craving, pride, and ignorance among the nine fetters are exhausted.ğŸ”½When the attainment of the complete knowledge of the faculty of pleasure occurs,
the exhaustion of desire for the heaven of complete purity is precisely the attainment of the complete knowledge of the faculty of pleasure.
At that time, one does not completely eliminate any of the ninety-eight latent afflictions.
Therefore, this is said.
The rest should be understood in the same way.
However, there are seventeen stages in which one attains complete knowledge.
That is, at the time of the four forbearances and four knowledges of the dharma realm, and the four forbearances and four knowledges of the subsequent stage,
One only attains complete knowledge of the dharmas eliminated by seeing.
From the desire realm up to the sphere of nothingness,
At the time of the exhaustion of craving for the eight stages, one attains complete knowledge of the dharmas eliminated by both seeing and cultivation.
At the time of the exhaustion of craving for the single stage of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception,
One only attains complete knowledge of the dharmas eliminated by cultivation.
The dharmas are called complete knowledge in these seventeen stages.
Speaking according to their corresponding characteristics, fearing the text would be too extensive, they are not separately shown.
The eye faculty, up to the latent afflictions eliminated by cultivation in the formless realm,
At the time of the realization of the cessation of each one,
Among the ninety-eight latent afflictions,
How many latent afflictions are realized as ceased?
How many of the nine fetters are exhausted?
Why is this treatise composed?
The answer is: in order to stop other schools and reveal the correct principle.
This means that some people hold the view that
when the diamond-like concentration is present,
all the afflictions to be eliminated by seeing and cultivation in the three realms are suddenly eliminated.
Before this, the various stages can only subdue the entanglements and are unable to eliminate the proclivities.
Like the Å›ramaá¹‡as who eliminate suddenly.
They say that one suddenly attains the fruit of arhatship.
Like when one wakes from a dream and suddenly abandons drowsiness.
In order to stop this idea and reveal the elimination of the proclivities,
there are eighty-nine distinctions in stages.
Because in all these stages one realizes cessation.
Or there are some who hold the view thatğŸ”½only the uninterrupted path can eliminate the proclivities and obtain them.
Only the path of liberation can realize their cessation.
Like the Western Å›ramaá¹‡as, they say:
The uninterrupted path does not eliminate afflictions.
The path of liberation does not realize their cessation.
In order to stop this idea and reveal that the uninterrupted path can eliminate afflictions,
because it cuts off the obtainment of afflictions and prevents their continuation.
Because it can also realize cessation and cause the acquisition of disjunction to arise.
The paths of liberation are only called the realization of cessation.
Because they are present together with the acquisition of disjunction.
Moreover, in order to reveal the principle of realizing cessation and cause the wise to know it, this treatise is composed.
There are two kinds of realization of dharmas in brief.
First, realization by knowledge.
Second, realization by acquisition.
Realization by knowledge means
the knowledge of all dharmas.
It can realize and know.
Realization by acquisition means
the wholesome dharmas, the universal fruits, and the acquisitions can realize and obtain.
Here, it only speaks of realization by acquisition.
Among them, it only speaks of realization of cessation.
Cessation refers to cessation through discernment.
In all states, the acquisition of realizing cessation is called the realization of cessation.
This realization of cessation, according to the distinctions in states, has eighty-nine.
That is, at the time of the four forbearances and knowledges of dharmas, and the four forbearances and knowledges of types.

and when the nine uninterrupted and liberated paths of the nine stages are cultivated, and when the four Dharma and four species of patience and knowledge are cultivated, one only realizes the cessation of dharmas that are to be eliminated by seeing.
When the first eight uninterrupted and liberated paths of the stage of neither perception nor non-perception are cultivated,
one only realizes the cessation of dharmas that are to be eliminated by cultivation.
In the remaining seventy-three states, one realizes the cessation of dharmas that are to be eliminated by both seeing and cultivation.
Moreover, there are five general states in which one realizes cessation.
That is, when the counteracting paths of each category are cultivated,
and when one realizes the four fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a,
and when one sharpens one's faculties.

One should say there are six, but because when one sharpens one's faculties one necessarily realizes a fruit, it is subsumed within the four fruits, and therefore it is said that there are five states.ğŸ”½The afflictions that are to be eliminated by seeing and cultivation in the three realms,
when they realize cessation in these five states, there are those that are complete and those that are not.
There are some afflictions that have only one state,
namely the ninth category of afflictions to be eliminated by cultivation in the stage of neither perception nor non-perception.
This is when one realizes the fruit of arhatship.
There are some afflictions that have only two states,
Namely, the first eight categories of the stage of neither perception nor non-perception that are to be eliminated by cultivation,
and the first nine categories of the seven lower stages that are to be eliminated by cultivation.
When one cultivates the path that counteracts each of these categories,
and when one realizes the fruit of arhatship,
the ninth category of the desire realm that is to be eliminated by cultivation also has two times.
Namely, when one realizes the latter two fruits.
There are afflictions that have only three times.
Namely, the seventh and eighth categories of the desire realm that are to be eliminated by cultivation, when one cultivates the path that counteracts each of these categories,
and when one realizes the latter two Å›ramaá¹‡a fruits.
The sixth category of the desire realm that is to be eliminated by cultivation also has three times.
Namely, when one realizes the latter three Å›ramaá¹‡a fruits.
There are afflictions that have only four times.
Namely, the categories to be eliminated by seeing the path in the form and formless realms,
when one realizes the four Å›ramaá¹‡a fruits.
The first five categories of the desire realm that are to be eliminated by cultivation also have four times.
Namely, when one cultivates the path that counteracts each of these categories,
and when one realizes the latter three Å›ramaá¹‡a fruits.
Some afflictions have all five times.
Namely, those abandoned by seeing suffering, origin, and cessation in the three realms,
and those abandoned by seeing the path in the desire realm.
At the time of the antidote to each of their own categories,
and at the time of realizing the four fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
This is said based on the realization of cessation by the noble ones.
If based on ordinary beings, those abandoned by seeing and cultivation in the eight stages,
are all called the realization of cessation at the time of the antidote to each of their own categories.
The time of realizing the cessation of other contaminated dharmas should be understood according to the previous afflictions.
The realization of cessation through the forty-two chapters on the stages of the eye faculty and so forth is explained in the Abhidharma-Å›Ästra.
Question: What is the difference between the gate of complete knowledge in the previous section and the gate of realizing cessation in this section?
Answer: The gate of complete knowledge in the previous section shows the difference in obtaining abandonment at the time of the ultimate exhaustion of the eye faculty and so forth.
The gate of realizing cessation in this section shows the difference in realizing cessation at the time of the ultimate exhaustion of the eye faculty and so forth,
and in the subsequent stages.
Because in the subsequent stages, one repeatedly realizes the cessation of the eye faculty, etc., and obtains a single flavor.
The Western masters explain it like this.
The previous gate of complete knowledge shows the attainment of eliminating afflictions by the uninterrupted path.
The gate of realizing cessation shows the attainment of liberation by the liberation path.
The masters of this country explain it like this.
The previous gate of complete knowledge only shows the attainment of eliminating afflictions by the uninterrupted path.
The gate of realizing cessation shows the attainment of liberation by the uninterrupted and liberation paths.
Furthermore, the previous gate of complete knowledge only shows the attainment of complete knowledge of elimination in the initial stage.
The gate of realizing cessation shows the realization of cessation in the beginning and end.
This is the difference between the two gates of complete knowledge and realizing cessation.
Among these ten gates, the previously mentioned forty-two chapters have five different stages.
The previously mentioned forty-two chapters are divided into three categories.
Namely, the twenty-two faculties.
Up to the eliminated by seeing and cultivation.
The name of the eliminated by neither is the category of objects.
The four noble truths up to the three levels of samÄdhi are called the class of merits.
The three fetters up to the ninety-eight latent afflictions are called the class of faults.
Among the classes of objects, the twenty-two faculties
are the first because they are the most numerous, so they are made into a separate category.
Among the classes of faults, the ninety-eight latent afflictions
are the last because they are the most numerous, so they are made into a separate category.
The remaining three classes of dharmas each make up a category, so there are a total of five.
Among the five categories, those with similar characteristics are each briefly classified together.
Those with dissimilar characteristics are each broadly distinguished.
The wise should understand this well.
Here, the Venerable One generally uses ten topics
to include the previously mentioned forty-two chapters.
Among them, there are also many distinctions.
Namely, the cessation of the eye faculty up to the cessation of the ignorance eliminated by cultivation in the formless realm.
